tail: JKP. The custom is to show the way to a stranger. 3196. Ada ya mja, hunena: mwungwana ni kitendo. F.l.l; T.l; MS.2; SACL.40, 539; B.1.38; J., ada; V. p.2, ada ya mtumwa. There are two different translations: 1. Public opinion maintains: "A gentleman is judged by his actions." F. "A slave talks, a free man acts". SACL. V. 2. The custom of a slave is to talk [with] the free-born, it is action. T. The favorite explanation seems to be the first. JK avoids the difficulty: Mungwana ni tendo. JK.133. A gentleman is deeds [not mere words].
MA.5. Good manners is civilization.

quote: Adabu si adhabu, faida yake yaonekana mtoto  akuapo.
tail: MA.8. Good manners is not a punishment, the good of it is seen when a child grows up. Used to stop a child short when it objects to rules of conduct.
JKP. One who comes must call "hodi." No one is allowed to enter a private house without express invitation Hodi: the word that announces a visitor's presence outside the door.
, It is not fitting for you to enter another's house without their express permission. JKP. The invitation is karibu: welcome, come in.

quote: Ajaye bila ya kadi huondoka pasi na kuaga.
tail: NGU. The one who comes without a card leaves without saying good bye. Kadi: a letter of invitation, an I.D. cf. #1367.
NGU. Don't scrutinize the person who arrives. Cf.#? Karibu mgeni, lakini humwekei macho
KB.4. If you invite yourself bring your own chair. Behave humbly. Cf. #1367.
AL, kibaba. If you invite yourself, you must look for your own stool. Kibaba: a container for measuring, volume of about 1 liter or a pint.
NGU. When angry that person shouts, and when tired, complains. A moody person.

quote: Anayekuja pasi na hodi, huondoka pasi na kuaga.
tail: F.3.23; B.4.12; AL 1160. Who comes in without "May I come in," leaves without "Goodbye." About a person who comes without a warning. A person without manners is incorrigible. AL.

quote: Anayewahi au achelewaye kwa mtemi huambua  mzoga.
person: KA. A guest who arrives early at the chief's courtyard or leaves late removes a dead body. Being dead tired of all the extra work that person is asked to do. Know when to come and when to leave. It's not good to put yourself forward. This is said of those who come early or late.
tail: EM.12.14, KA. A guest who arrives early at the chief's courtyard or leaves late removes a dead body. Being dead tired of all the extra work that person is asked to do. Know when to come and when to leave. It's not good to put yourself forward. This is said of those who come early or late.
. NGU. "Pardon me" is not an insult. Ashkum: excuse me, forgive me.
EM.15.19. Asiye na adabu hajali wenzake. KA. A person who has no manners does not care about others. Lack of manners shows contempt for others. Cf.#? Asiyejua utu si mtu.

quote: Asiyefunzwa na mamaye, hufunzwa na ulimwengu.
tail: F.4.32; L.6; SWA.64; H.13; MARA.6; KB.25. A child who is not taught by its mother will be taught by the world. If a child is not taught good manners by its parents, it will have to learn them in the school of hard knocks. SWA.

. ED.4 A child who is not taught by its mother will be bruised by the world. Nina or mama yake: his or her mother. Fundwa in Standard Swahili means: to be pounded; but in Lamu dialect it has the meaning of -funza = to learn.

quote: Asiyefunzwa na wazazi atafunzwa na dunia.
tail: NGU; MEM.315. Those who are not taught [manners] by their parents, will be taught by the world. Cf. #418, #419.

quote: Atambaaye na nyasi mtambulie ni nyoka.
tail: KS, nyoka. What creeps in the grass, recognize it as a snake.

quote: Fanya heshima kwa wazee hata kama  si wako
tail: . NGU. Honor the elders, even if they are not yours.

quote: Farasi huenda kwa hatamu; punda huenda kwa  mchapo.
tail: NGU. A horse obeys the bridle, a donkey goes when hit. Different methods, same results.
REK. Lost respect is like a broken egg. It cannot be repaired.
SAM.8.5. Respect is free. It does not cost anything to honor a person.
. NGU. Courtesy is to respect each other
KS, utumwa. Courtesy is not slavery. Cf. #.3216.

. KS, utumwa; FSM 523. Saying "That's right" is not the same as slavery. Hewala from ewaa! or eewaa!: intonation commonly used in assent by inferiors or slaves ("Yes, Master"); also of approval ("Just so, that's right"). From the Arabic Ee Wallah: yes by God. Cf. inshallah, wallahi: God willing. J., ewaa.

F.11.18. "All right" and "thank you" does not cause disagreement. Civility does not cause disagreement. Civility costs nothing but is worth much. F. Hewalla: Corruption of an Arabic term meaning "All right," "thank you." F. Cf.1372 note
EM j14. Correct yourself before you correct others. If you are not a perfect example, others will not follow you nor listen to you. EM.
NGU. A rooster does not crow in a strange environment. Cf. #1637; #883.
KS, kadiri. Sit in your proper place. Cf. #1109.
NGU. Behave yourself.

quote: Kama si kizuri usifanye, kama  si kweli usiseme.
tail: NGU. If it is not nice don't do it, if it is not true don't say it.
JKP. Welcome is a courtesy, not [an invitation to] eating. It does not mean that one is invited to a meal.
F.14.5; T.131; A.95; MS.142; LOBO.167; V.120; SACL.337; KB., kawaida: KS, sheria Custom is lawlike. Kawaida: a custom practised of old, unwritten law.

quote: Ada ya nchi kwa wenyewe ni sheria.
tail: MA.2 A country's customs and traditions are laws for the inhabitants. A country's culture and all that goes with it, should be respected. MM.
JKP. To look at a hidden thing is not proper. Sita: to halt, to hide. Steere. Cf. #1768A for more explanation.

quote: Kiti cha mkewe si cha kukalia
tail: . REK. The chair of the housewife is not for sitting on. Don't interfere with other people's business. A chair has a special value in most cultures.

quote: Kitwitwi akishindwa kumwaga mgeni, anaugua  wazimu.
tail: AL 1162. If the sandpiper is unable to say goodbye to his host, [its excuse] is that it is suffering from hallucinations. Somebody looking for an excuse in breaking the rule of good manners.
NGU. Paying respect is not the same as being afraid. Cf.#975.
JKP. It does not harm to be of service. "Said by one who offers to help." JKP.
EM k25. Judging is judging oneself. When you judge another person, you are also judging yourself for you are showing your stand. EM.

quote: Kuku anakula kadiri ya mdomo wake.
tail: KB.122. A chicken eats according to its beak. Avoid exaggeration. Cf. #147; #232.
KB.123. A chicken does not crow in the presence of a rooster. One should keep one's place. KB.
. MA.227. To bother one another is not a thing a free man does. It is not a good thing to cause trouble for another.
MP.226.7. Politeness is not slavery. Being polite does not necessarily mean servitude or base flattery.
EM s9. Gratitude is not servitude. Lebeka or labeka: at your service; used by a youngster when called by its father or mother. Lamka and lama are also used.

quote: Mbwa hata awe wa kizungu, haachi kunusa vyombo.
tail: NGU. Even a European dog does not leave sniffing pots.
KA. A dog always sniffs the pots. Comes naturally.
AL 1175. Among people a dog does not speak. It's better not to interfere in other people's business. AL.

quote: Mchama ago hanyeli, huenda akauya papo.
tail: F.23.31; KA. Delicately translated by F: "A traveler does not make a mess where he makes camp as he might one day come back to the same place". Mchama: one who moves, a traveller. Ago, kambi: camp. Akauya, akaja or akarudi: comes back, returns.
FSM.194. Do not do your call of nature in the camp. Cf. #610.
SAM.14.8. One who follows the rules will profit by them.
KB.180; AL 1135 A stranger cannot see the moon. A stranger is not able to know the customs of the inhabitants. A stranger is ignorant until settled. A visitor cannot give advice. AL.
MEM.253. A stranger does not see the moon. Possibly the moon may stand for rites to be observed. AL.
MA.350. Stupid people do not know where they come from.

JK.120. You will talk in daytime, at night you will sleep. This is not only a general rule of conduct, but also, take counsel with your pillow. JK. Let them talk [do not kill yourself worrying], they will get tired. MM.

quote: Mtoto wa kuku, kausha mdomo ule.
tail: AL 443; AL, mtoto. Chick, dry your beak and eat. A child is told to grow up and act like an adult.
T.349; SACL.237; KB., funza, omits adabu. An intelligent servant does not need to be taught good manners. KB., SACL.

T.350. "Born here" is the sensible slave. T. A slave of the first or second generation gets accustomed to the ways of the coast; in contrast to the mshenzi from the interior, that never quite loses clumsiness. T. Azawao (aliyezaliwa pwani): one born on the coast.

quote: Mwana mtumishi hula chake na cha mwenziwe
tail: . T. 367. A child sent on an errand eats its own food and its companion's. A messenger usually benefits from errands made. MM. A child who is willing to do errands [to do what it is told] will be rewarded.

quote: Mwana msikizi hula chake na cha mwenziwe.
tail: T. 643b. The obedient child eats its own [food] and its companion's.
NGU. A kid [of a goat] sweeps where it sleeps. Its tail sweeps the place before lying down.
KB.219. One who squats [call of nature] is not ashamed. One must tolerate human needs.

quote: Mwenye kufuama haoni haya, kefu yule mwenye  kuangalia
tail: . AL 1168. One who squats is without shame, but the one who stares at that person should be ashamed. Natural needs are human, but also secret. Fuama or Fulama or furama.
. V., mwiza; SACL. 651. [To say] "yes, yes" is not slavery. Reverence is not slavery. SACL. Being agreeable is not the same as becoming a slave. Cf.1372; #1376.

quote: Mwungwana asiye ari kama  ng'ombe asiye na pembe
tail: . L.77; SACL..71; V., asiyoari. The civilized person not making an effort [to avoid disgrace] is like a cow that has no horns. L. A gentleman without self respect is like a bull without horns. SACL. A gentleman who does not care about others is like an ox without horns. V. Ari: shame; effort to avoid the disgrace of being thought incompetent. L. Mwungwana: a free man.

quote: Mwungwana hanuni kwa masmavu, hununa moyoni.
tail: A.73; Lobo.l; SAM.19.44;SACL..691; T.359; KB. 225; AL, nuna. Civilized persons pout not with their cheeks, they pout in their heart A. A gentleman does not sulk ostentatiously, but sulks in silence, when defeated. Suffer insults silently. An intelligent person does not show worries or hatred. SAM. And stays master of self. AL.
FK. I hold a tradition where there is no choice. FK As a warning to desert old customs for new ones. FK.

F.38.5; B.3.71; F., mazoewa; AL 1695. A bird that imitates has no good behavior or culture. AL. A bird that imitates others does not get used to a place. F. A stranger always looks how others behave while eating.

quote: Ndiyo, ndiyo, jua lako, usijue ya mwenzako.
tail: AL 1174. Indeed, know your problems, don't try to know those of your friend.

quote: Ni lipi lisilo nduguye na mwamu wake?
tail: V.67; T. 429; SACL. 639. What [affair] is there that has not its in-laws? T. If you treat a guest inhospitably, know that your own turn may come to be treated likewise. As you do to me, so I'll do to you. V.

quote: Nilimwona mnyama katika makundi, kenda  kamwegema;  kanipiga pindi.
tail: SACL.750. I saw an animal in a herd [in a crowd], I went [I tried] to make acquaintance; it went away like a snake (turned its back on me). Piga pindi: zigzag as a snake, undulating. Egema: to trust to.
REK. The he-goats greet each other with their horns. Beberu: he-goat; a strong man.

quote: Shitaka kwa nyani au kwa ngedere hukumu moja.
tail: EM s7. The judgment of a case submitted to an ape or a monkey is the same. People of the same kind give a similar judgment or answer. EM.

quote: Sionje haramu kwani ni kama  sumu.
tail: JKP. Don't taste anything forbidden [like adultery], it is like poison.
MARA 2. Character is like one's skin. One cannot change one's skin. It is equally hard to change one's character.

quote: Tabia ya mtu ni kia cha mwili.
tail: MARA 2. The character of a person is like a joint of the body Kia, kiungo: joint.
A.95; T.514. Are you a child or a grit? Don't you hear at all? Are you altogether shameless? Kamange: a bean or seed that is still hard after cooking; a person who does not want to behave.
T.100. What shall they do to a grit for it ever to become soft? Kauta: dust, grit.
NGU. The filth of your relative does not cause you to vomit.

quote: Ujinga huo wa kuacha kinywa kutia puani.
tail: AL 1157. This stupidity of removing your finger from your mouth and putting it in your nose. In society the rules of good behavior are to be observed. AL.

quote: Ukenda kwa wenye chongo, [nawe] vunja lako jicho.
tail: T.522; F.46.5; AL 359. When you visit one-eyed people, destroy also your own eye. One must howl with the wolves. V.; ED. When in Rome, do as the Romans. If you want to be more shrewd than your companions you are taking risks. AL.

quote: Ukenda kwa mwenye chongo, nawe fumba lako jicho.
tail: MARA 2; ED 84. If you go visiting a person with one eye, you better close also one eye.

quote: Ukikaa mji wa mwenye chongo, nawe vunja lako jicho.
tail: V.47. If you live in a village of a one-eyed person, destroy also one of your eyes.
EMu7. If you go to Pemba, you should wear a turban. Cf.#289 Waarabu wa Pemba...
. NGU. If you go to Rome, do as the Romans do.

quote: Ukienda usiage, ukirudi u mgeni wa nani?
tail: AL 1161. If you leave without saying goodbye, coming back who will invite you?

quote: Ukikaa na simba, vaa ngozi ya mamba.
tail: RSP.141. If you live with a lion, wear the skin of a crocodile.

quote: Ukila pamwe na namiri, igiza zao desturi.
tail: RSP. 91. If you eat with the leopards, imitate their habits.
SACL. 950; AL, ulibwende. Finery asks for class. Finery needs taste and money.

quote: Umekaa kama ngawa, kwani huna mazoea.
tail: T.540; SACL .521. You behave like a civet-cat, don't you know how to behave? Said of someone who does not associate with others.

quote: Usichekelee mbwa kuchutama, hujui ukao wake.
tail: AL 665. Don't laugh at a dog squatting, don't you know that it is his normal pose. Don't judge others. AL.
NGU. Don't mock the little joke of your in-law. Kicheko: laugh, smile, giggle, grin

quote: Usiwe joka la mndimu, hatundi hatikizi  watundao.
tail: JK.146. Do not be like the lemon tree snake: it does not pick the fruits nor does it tolerate the pickers. JK. Live and let live. JK. Cf. #1057.

quote: Usiwe kidoa cha kuharibu nguo za wenzio.
tail: SAM. 25.17. Don't be a stain spoiling the clothes of your companions. Said of people who are envious of others and do not maintain the standards of the group. MM. Cf. #1399.
T.546; V.ll9, ndirama. Gentle birth avails not, the important thing is money. Money rules the world. Ndarama or dhirahmu,darahima, darahimu or dharamu : drachmas; fig., riches. Sacl.

quote: Vijana hawana hekima, hisana wala kupendana.
tail: JKP. Children have no wisdom, kindness, or love. "They have to learn all those." JKP.
NGU. The people with objections are unbreakable. There always will be objections. Wakinzani: obstructionists.
JK.146. If the natives eat rats, eat rats.
JKP. You can [say] Stay, you cannot [say] Get out.
